title: Anatomy-Informed Deep Learning and Radiomics for Automated Neurofibroma Segmentation in Whole-Body MRI
author: Georgii Kolokolnikov (University Medical Center Hamburg-Eppendorf), Marie-Lena Schmalhofer (University Medical Center Hamburg-Eppendorf), Lennart Well (University Medical Center Hamburg-Eppendorf), Said Farschtschi (University Medical Center Hamburg-Eppendorf), Victor-Felix Mautner (University Medical Center Hamburg-Eppendorf), Inka Ristow (University Medical Center Hamburg-Eppendorf), Rene Werner (University Medical Center Hamburg-Eppendorf), ...
relevance_why: The use of deep learning techniques and ensemble methods for segmentation tasks is relevant as similar approaches could enhance audio signal processing tasks, such as sound source separation.
background: Automated segmentation in medical imaging aims to identify and delineate regions of interest, such as tumors, accurately from MRI scans.
contribution: This paper introduces a three-stage pipeline that employs anatomy-informed neural networks for accurate neurofibroma segmentation, achieving significant improvements in Dice Similarity Coefficient and F1 score.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous methods had limitations in segmentation accuracy due to inconsistencies in tumor appearance and were often semi-automated, requiring user intervention.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work improves segmentation by using a fully automated pipeline that integrates anatomical knowledge and radiomic features to refine tumor detection and reduce false positives.

key_innovation: The incorporation of anatomy segmentation as context for the neural networks enhances the model's focus on high-risk areas for tumor development.
real_world_impact: The method's integration into clinical platforms like 3D Slicer signals its potential for improving patient care through enhanced tumor monitoring and assessment.
limitations: The pipeline's performance is sensitive to variations in MRI protocols and low tumor burden cases.

new_terms.Dice Similarity Coefficient: **Dice Similarity Coefficient** is a statistical measure used to gauge the similarity of two samples, often utilized in medical imaging to evaluate the accuracy of segmentation.
new_terms.radiomic features: **Radiomic features** are quantitative characteristics extracted from medical images that can be used for predictive modeling and analysis in various medical contexts.

open_sourcing: The code for the segmentation pipeline is publicly accessible at https://github.com/IPMI-ICNS-UKE/NFSegmentationPipeline.
